For more information on this research see: Isolation of a methane oxidising bacterium that bioremediates hexavalent chromium from a formerly industrialised suburban river. text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals &
Chemistry Daily Daily \-- Current study results on Microbiology have been
published. According to news reporting from Sheffield, United Kingdom, by
NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Sediment samples were taken from
sediment adjacent to an urban river in Sheffield in Northern England that had
suffered heavy metal pollution due to previous activity of the steel industry
(between the 17th and 19th centuries)."

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Sheffield
Hallam University, "The most abundant heavy metals found in the samples were
lead, chromium, nickel, arsenic and cobalt, with maximum concentrations of
412.80 mg kg 25.232 mg kg , 25.196 mg kg , 8.123 mg kg and 7.66 mg kg ,
respectively. Enrichment cultures were set up using methane as carbon and
energy source, as a result of which a strain of methanotroph was isolated that
was shown via 16S rRNA gene sequencing to be a strain Methylomonas koyamae and
given the designation SHU1. M. koyamae SHU1 removed hexavalent chromium from
an initial concentration of 10 ppm, which was inhibited by the metabolic
inhibitor sodium azide or the methane monooxygenase inhibitor
phenylacetylene."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "To the authors'
knowledge this is the first description of a strain of the widely
environmentally distributed genus Methylomonas that is capable of remediating
hexavalent chromium."

For more information on this research see: Isolation of a methane oxidising
bacterium that bioremediates hexavalent chromium from a formerly
industrialised suburban river. _Letters In Applied Microbiology_ , 2020;():.
_Letters In Applied Microbiology_ can be contacted at: Blackwell Publishing
Inc, 350 Main St, Malden, MA 02148, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell -
<http://www.wiley.com/>; Letters In Applied Microbiology -
<http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1472-765X>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting T.J. Smith, Biomolecular Sciences Research Centre, College of
Heath, Wellbeing and Life Sciences, Sheffield Hallam University, Sheffield,
UK.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1111/lam.13330>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the journal _Letters In Applied
Microbiology_ is: Blackwell Publishing Inc, 350 Main St, Malden, MA 02148,
USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Researchers from Sheffield Hallam University Describe Findings in Microbiology (Isolation of a methane oxidising bacterium that bioremediates hexavalent chromium from a formerly industrialised suburban river): Microbiology
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals & Chemistry Daily Daily -- Current study results on Microbiology have been published. According to news reporting from Sheffield, United Kingdom, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Sediment samples were taken from sediment adjacent to an urban river in Sheffield in Northern England that had suffered heavy metal pollution due to previous activity of the steel industry (between the 17th and 19th centuries).”

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Sheffield Hallam University, “The most abundant heavy metals found in the samples were lead, chromium, nickel, arsenic and cobalt, with maximum concentrations of 412.80 mg kg 25.232 mg kg , 25.196 mg kg , 8.123 mg kg and 7.66 mg kg , respectively. Enrichment cultures were set up using methane as carbon and energy source, as a result of which a strain of methanotroph was isolated that was shown via 16S rRNA gene sequencing to be a strain Methylomonas koyamae and given the designation SHU1. M. koyamae SHU1 removed hexavalent chromium from an initial concentration of 10 ppm, which was inhibited by the metabolic inhibitor sodium azide or the methane monooxygenase inhibitor phenylacetylene.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “To the authors’ knowledge this is the first description of a strain of the widely environmentally distributed genus Methylomonas that is capable of remediating hexavalent chromium.”

For more information on this research see: Isolation of a methane oxidising bacterium that bioremediates hexavalent chromium from a formerly industrialised suburban river. Letters In Applied Microbiology, 2020;():. Letters In Applied Microbiology can be contacted at: Blackwell Publishing Inc, 350 Main St, Malden, MA 02148, USA. (Wiley-Blackwell - http://www.wiley.com/; Letters In Applied Microbiology - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1472-765X)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting T.J. Smith, Biomolecular Sciences Research Centre, College of Heath, Wellbeing and Life Sciences, Sheffield Hallam University, Sheffield, UK.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1111/lam.13330. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the journal Letters In Applied Microbiology is: Blackwell Publishing Inc, 350 Main St, Malden, MA 02148, USA.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
